I would recommend this game to literally anyone who likes simracing or cars, so much fun.

I’ve clocked 1.1k hours in Assetto Corsa, and here’s the deal: it’s fun, especially if you’ve got friends to race with. The gameplay itself is solid, but the graphics? Yeah, they’re a bit outdated. You’ll need mods to make it look good—without them, it feels like you’re stuck in 2014.

Forza? Honestly, it does most things better—better graphics, smoother experience, and it’s more polished overall. But Assetto Corsa has its charm. If you can grab it cheap, it’s worth it. Just don’t expect to be blown away by the visuals out of the box.

Achievement hunting is a whole different beast. There are 709 achievements, and let me tell you, it wasn’t easy. It took a lot of difficulty and patience, but I managed to get them all. So, if you’re into achievement hunting, be prepared for a grind.

One thing to note: if you want to race with friends, you’ll need to shell out some cash for a server, unless you’re clever and use something like World Sim Series (WSS) to host your own events.

At the end of the day, it’s a great game if you’ve got the mods and the setup. It’s a lot of fun with friends, but it’s a bit of a grind unless you’re into the nitty-gritty.

I've never played a better driving game and I've played a lot.

If you're in doubt (as I was), grab the Ultimate edition on sale.  It gives you enough content to understand the simulation model and it's well worth the price.

Where the games shines though, is in the mods.  Mostly, this involves dropping files into Content Manager (free) or unzipping into the correct directory, but the stuff that's available is kinda insane.

If you've got a favourite car of track, it's probably available as a mod.  And then there's the stuff like Shutoko Revivial Project that elevate the game into a whole new level.

Absolutely recommended (and get a wheel if you don't have one).
